name: 1613_E. Crazy Robot
description:
There is a grid, consisting of n rows and m columns. Each cell of the grid is either free or blocked. One of the free cells contains a lab. All the cells beyond the borders of the grid are also blocked.

A crazy robot has escaped from this lab. It is currently in some free cell of the grid. You can send one of the following commands to the robot: "move right", "move down", "move left" or "move up". Each command means moving to a neighbouring cell in the corresponding direction.

However, as the robot is crazy, it will do anything except following the command. Upon receiving a command, it will choose a direction such that it differs from the one in command and the cell in that direction is not blocked. If there is such a direction, then it will move to a neighbouring cell in that direction. Otherwise, it will do nothing.

We want to get the robot to the lab to get it fixed. For each free cell, determine if the robot can be forced to reach the lab starting in this cell. That is, after each step of the robot a command can be sent to a robot such that no matter what different directions the robot chooses, it will end up in a lab.

Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains two integers n and m (1 ≤ n, m ≤ 10^6; n ⋅ m ≤ 10^6) — the number of rows and the number of columns in the grid.

The i-th of the next n lines provides a description of the i-th row of the grid. It consists of m elements of one of three types: 

  * '.' — the cell is free; 
  * '#' — the cell is blocked; 
  * 'L' — the cell contains a lab. 



The grid contains exactly one lab. The sum of n ⋅ m over all testcases doesn't exceed 10^6.

Output

For each testcase find the free cells that the robot can be forced to reach the lab from. Given the grid, replace the free cells (marked with a dot) with a plus sign ('+') for the cells that the robot can be forced to reach the lab from. Print the resulting grid.

Example

Input


4
3 3
...
.L.
...
4 5
#....
..##L
...#.
.....
1 1
L
1 9
....L..#.


Output


...
.L.
...
#++++
..##L
...#+
...++
L
++++L++#.

Note

In the first testcase there is no free cell that the robot can be forced to reach the lab from. Consider a corner cell. Given any direction, it will move to a neighbouring border grid that's not a corner. Now consider a non-corner free cell. No matter what direction you send to the robot, it can choose a different direction such that it ends up in a corner.

In the last testcase, you can keep sending the command that is opposite to the direction to the lab and the robot will have no choice other than move towards the lab.
prompt:
There exists a grid, made up of n rows and m columns. Each cell in the grid is either unoccupied or blocked, and one of the unoccupied cells contains a laboratory. All cells outside the grid's limits are also blocked.

A crazy robot has escaped from this lab and is currently in some free cell of the grid. You can send one of the following commands to the robot: "move right", "move down", "move left" or "move up", where each command means moving to a neighbouring cell in the corresponding direction. 

However, because the robot is crazy, it will do anything except obey the command. Upon being given a command, it will choose to move in a direction that is not specified in the command. It will select a direction where the cell in that direction is not blocked, and then proceed to a neighbouring cell in that direction if it exists; otherwise, it will remain stationary.

We want to get the robot to the lab to get it fixed. For each free cell, determine if the robot can be forced to reach the lab starting in this cell. That is, after each step of the robot a command can be sent to a robot such that no matter what different directions the robot chooses, it will end up in a lab.

Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains two integers n and m (1 ≤ n, m ≤ 10^6; n ⋅ m ≤ 10^6) — the number of rows and the number of columns in the grid.

The i-th of the next n lines provides a description of the i-th row of the grid. It consists of m elements of one of three types: 

  * '.' — the cell is free; 
  * '#' — the cell is blocked; 
  * 'L' — the cell contains a lab. 



The grid contains exactly one lab. The sum of n ⋅ m over all testcases doesn't exceed 10^6.

Output

For each testcase find the free cells that the robot can be forced to reach the lab from. Given the grid, replace the free cells (marked with a dot) with a plus sign ('+') for the cells that the robot can be forced to reach the lab from. Print the resulting grid.

Example

Input


4
3 3
...
.L.
...
4 5
#....
..##L
...#.
.....
1 1
L
1 9
....L..#.


Output


...
.L.
...
#++++
..##L
...#+
...++
L
++++L++#.

Note

In the first testcase there is no free cell that the robot can be forced to reach the lab from. Consider a corner cell. Given any direction, it will move to a neighbouring border grid that's not a corner. Now consider a non-corner free cell. No matter what direction you send to the robot, it can choose a different direction such that it ends up in a corner.

In the last testcase, you can keep sending the command that is opposite to the direction to the lab and the robot will have no choice other than move towards the lab.
repair_prompt:
There exists a grid, made up of n rows and m columns. Each cell in the grid is either unoccupied or blocked, and one of the unoccupied cells contains a laboratory. All cells outside the grid's limits are also blocked.

A crazy robot has escaped from this lab and is currently in some free cell of the grid. You can send one of the following commands to the robot: "move right", "move down", "move left" or "move up", where each command means moving to a neighbouring cell in the corresponding direction. 

However, because the robot is crazy, it will do anything except obey the command. Upon being given a command, it will choose to move in a direction that is not specified in the command. It will select a direction where the cell in that direction is not blocked, and then proceed to a neighbouring cell in that direction if it exists; otherwise, it will remain stationary.

We want to get the robot to the lab to get it fixed. For each free cell, determine if the robot can be forced to reach the lab starting in this cell. That is, after each step of the robot a command can be sent to a robot such that no matter what different directions the robot chooses, it will end up in a lab.

Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains two integers n and m (1 ≤ n, m ≤ 10^6; n ⋅ m ≤ 10^6) — the number of rows and the number of columns in the grid.

The i-th of the next n lines provides a description of the i-th row of the grid. It consists of m elements of one of three types: 

  * '.' — the cell is free; 
  * '#' — the cell is blocked; 
  * 'L' — the cell contains a lab. 



The grid contains exactly one lab. The sum of n ⋅ m over all testcases doesn't exceed 10^6.

Output

For each testcase find the free cells that the robot can be forced to reach the lab from. Given the grid, replace the free cells (marked with a dot) with a plus sign ('+') for the cells that the robot can be forced to reach the lab from. Print the resulting grid.

-------
Important Note: You must follow the input output format.  The code will be tested against multiple test cases and all the test cases must be passed.
Example

Input


4
3 3
...
.L.
...
4 5
#....
..##L
...#.
.....
1 1
L
1 9
....L..#.


Output


...
.L.
...
#++++
..##L
...#+
...++
L
++++L++#.

Note

In the first testcase there is no free cell that the robot can be forced to reach the lab from. Consider a corner cell. Given any direction, it will move to a neighbouring border grid that's not a corner. Now consider a non-corner free cell. No matter what direction you send to the robot, it can choose a different direction such that it ends up in a corner.

In the last testcase, you can keep sending the command that is opposite to the direction to the lab and the robot will have no choice other than move towards the lab.

from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple
from collections import deque

def find_reachable_cells(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, List[str]]]) -> List[List[str]]:
    """Finds the free cells from which the robot can be forced to reach the lab.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing:
            - n: Number of rows in the grid.
            - m: Number of columns in the grid.
            - grid: A list of strings representing the grid.

    Returns:
        A list of grids with reachable cells marked with '+'.
    """
    def bfs(n: int, m: int, grid: List[str]) -> List[str]:
        """Performs BFS to find all reachable cells from the lab.

        Args:
            n: Number of rows in the grid.
            m: Number of columns in the grid.
            grid: A list of strings representing the grid.

        Returns:
            A modified grid with reachable cells marked with '+'.
        """
        directions = [(-1, 0), (1, 0), (0, -1), (0, 1)]
        lab_position = None
        visited = set()
        queue = deque()

        # Find the lab position and initialize the queue
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == 'L':
                    lab_position = (i, j)
                    queue.append(lab_position)
                    visited.add(lab_position)
                    break
            if lab_position:
                break

        # Perform BFS from the lab
        while queue:
            x, y = queue.popleft()
            for dx, dy in directions:
                nx, ny = x + dx, y + dy
                if 0 <= nx < n and 0 <= ny < m and (nx, ny) not in visited:
                    if grid[nx][ny] == '.':
                        # Check if the cell can be forced to reach the lab
                        free_neighbors = 0
                        for ddx, ddy in directions:
                            nnx, nny = nx + ddx, ny + ddy
                            if 0 <= nnx < n and 0 <= nny < m and grid[nnx][nny] == '.':
                                free_neighbors += 1
                        if free_neighbors <= 1:
                            queue.append((nx, ny))
                            visited.add((nx, ny))
                    elif grid[nx][ny] == 'L':
                        visited.add((nx, ny))

        # Mark reachable cells with '+'
        result_grid = []
        for i in range(n):
            row = []
            for j in range(m):
                if (i, j) in visited and grid[i][j] == '.':
                    row.append('+')
                else:
                    row.append(grid[i][j])
            result_grid.append(''.join(row))

        return result_grid

    results = []
    for n, m, grid in test_cases:
        results.append(bfs(n, m, grid))

    return results

# Input interface
t = int(input())
test_cases = []
for _ in range(t):
    n, m = map(int, input().split())
    grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
    test_cases.append((n, m, grid))

# Output interface
result = find_reachable_cells(t, test_cases)
for grid in result:
    for row in grid:
        print(row)
from typing import List
## main.py
from typing import List
from collections import deque

def find_reachable_cells(t: int, test_cases: List[List[str]]) -> List[List[str]]:
    def bfs(grid: List[str], n: int, m: int) -> List[str]:
        directions = [(-1, 0), (1, 0), (0, -1), (0, 1)]
        queue = deque()
        visited = set()
        
        # Find the lab position
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == 'L':
                    lab_position = (i, j)
                    queue.append(lab_position)
                    visited.add(lab_position)
                    break
        
        # Perform BFS from the lab
        while queue:
            x, y = queue.popleft()
            for dx, dy in directions:
                nx, ny = x + dx, y + dy
                if 0 <= nx < n and 0 <= ny < m and (nx, ny) not in visited:
                    if grid[nx][ny] == '.':
                        # Check if the cell can be forced to reach the lab
                        free_neighbors = 0
                        for ddx, ddy in directions:
                            nnx, nny = nx + ddx, ny + ddy
                            if 0 <= nnx < n and 0 <= nny < m and grid[nnx][nny] == '.':
                                free_neighbors += 1
                        if free_neighbors <= 1:
                            grid[nx] = grid[nx][:ny] + '+' + grid[nx][ny+1:]
                            queue.append((nx, ny))
                    visited.add((nx, ny))
        
        return grid

    result = []
    for grid in test_cases:
        n = len(grid)
        m = len(grid[0])
        modified_grid = bfs(grid, n, m)
        result.append(modified_grid)
    
    return result

# Input interface
if __name__ == "__main__":
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m = map(int, input().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append(grid)

    # Output interface
    result = find_reachable_cells(t, test_cases)
    for grid in result:
        for row in grid:
            print(row)
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple
from collections import deque

def find_reachable_cells(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, List[str]]]) -> List[List[str]]:
    """Finds the free cells from which the robot can be forced to reach the lab.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, int, List[str]]]): List of test cases, each containing:
            - n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
            - m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
            - grid (List[str]): The grid itself, represented as a list of strings.

    Returns:
        List[List[str]]: A list of processed grids where reachable free cells are marked with '+'.
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, grid in test_cases:
        # Convert grid to a mutable list of lists
        grid = [list(row) for row in grid]
        
        # Find the lab position
        lab_position = None
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == 'L':
                    lab_position = (i, j)
                    break
            if lab_position:
                break

        # Directions for BFS: right, down, left, up
        directions = [(0, 1), (1, 0), (0, -1), (-1, 0)]

        # BFS to find all reachable cells
        queue = deque([lab_position])
        visited = set([lab_position])

        while queue:
            x, y = queue.popleft()

            # Check all four possible directions
            for dx, dy in directions:
                nx, ny = x + dx, y + dy

                if 0 <= nx < n and 0 <= ny < m and (nx, ny) not in visited:
                    if grid[nx][ny] == '.':
                        # Check if the cell can be forced to reach the lab
                        free_neighbors = 0
                        for ddx, ddy in directions:
                            nnx, nny = nx + ddx, ny + ddy
                            if 0 <= nnx < n and 0 <= nny < m and grid[nnx][nny] == '.':
                                free_neighbors += 1
                        if free_neighbors <= 1:
                            grid[nx][ny] = '+'
                            queue.append((nx, ny))
                    visited.add((nx, ny))

        # Convert grid back to list of strings
        results.append([''.join(row) for row in grid])

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input().strip())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m = map(int, input().strip().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, grid))

    # Call the function
    result = find_reachable_cells(t, test_cases)

    # Output interface
    for grid in result:
        for row in grid:
            print(row)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple
from collections import deque

def find_reachable_cells(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, List[str]]]) -> List[List[str]]:
    """Determine which free cells can lead the robot to the lab using BFS.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, int, List[str]]]): List of test cases, each containing grid dimensions and grid.

    Returns:
        List[List[str]]: Modified grids with reachable cells marked.
    """
    def bfs(n: int, m: int, grid: List[str]) -> List[str]:
        """Perform BFS to find reachable cells from the lab.

        Args:
            n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
            m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
            grid (List[str]): The grid representation.

        Returns:
            List[str]: Modified grid with reachable cells marked.
        """
        directions = [(-1, 0), (1, 0), (0, -1), (0, 1)]
        lab_position = None
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == 'L':
                    lab_position = (i, j)
                    break
            if lab_position:
                break

        queue = deque([lab_position])
        visited = set([lab_position])
        reachable = set()

        while queue:
            x, y = queue.popleft()
            for dx, dy in directions:
                nx, ny = x + dx, y + dy
                if 0 <= nx < n and 0 <= ny < m and (nx, ny) not in visited:
                    if grid[nx][ny] == '.':
                        # Check if the cell is surrounded by blocked cells
                        free_neighbors = 0
                        for ddx, ddy in directions:
                            nnx, nny = nx + ddx, ny + ddy
                            if 0 <= nnx < n and 0 <= nny < m and grid[nnx][nny] == '.':
                                free_neighbors += 1
                        if free_neighbors <= 1:
                            reachable.add((nx, ny))
                            queue.append((nx, ny))
                    visited.add((nx, ny))

        # Modify the grid to mark reachable cells
        modified_grid = []
        for i in range(n):
            row = []
            for j in range(m):
                if (i, j) in reachable:
                    row.append('+')
                else:
                    row.append(grid[i][j])
            modified_grid.append(''.join(row))

        return modified_grid

    results = []
    for n, m, grid in test_cases:
        results.append(bfs(n, m, grid))

    return results

# Input interface
t = int(input())
test_cases = []
for _ in range(t):
    n, m = map(int, input().split())
    grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
    test_cases.append((n, m, grid))

# Output interface
result = find_reachable_cells(t, test_cases)
for grid in result:
    for row in grid:
        print(row)
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple
from collections import deque

def find_reachable_cells(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, List[str]]]) -> List[List[str]]:
    """Determine which free cells can lead the robot to the lab."""
    
    def flood_fill(n: int, m: int, grid: List[str]) -> List[str]:
        """Perform flood fill from the lab to mark reachable cells."""
        # Convert grid to a list of lists for mutability
        grid = [list(row) for row in grid]
        
        # Find the lab position
        lab_position = None
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == 'L':
                    lab_position = (i, j)
                    break
            if lab_position:
                break
        
        # Directions for flood fill (up, down, left, right)
        directions = [(-1, 0), (1, 0), (0, -1), (0, 1)]
        
        # Queue for BFS
        queue = deque([lab_position])
        
        # Perform BFS from the lab
        while queue:
            x, y = queue.popleft()
            for dx, dy in directions:
                nx, ny = x + dx, y + dy
                if 0 <= nx < n and 0 <= ny < m and grid[nx][ny] == '.':
                    # Count free neighbors
                    free_neighbors = 0
                    for ddx, ddy in directions:
                        nnx, nny = nx + ddx, ny + ddy
                        if 0 <= nnx < n and 0 <= nny < m and grid[nnx][nny] == '.':
                            free_neighbors += 1
                    # If the cell has at most one free neighbor, mark it as reachable
                    if free_neighbors <= 1:
                        grid[nx][ny] = '+'
                        queue.append((nx, ny))
        
        # Convert grid back to list of strings
        return [''.join(row) for row in grid]
    
    # Process each test case
    result = []
    for n, m, grid in test_cases:
        result.append(flood_fill(n, m, grid))
    
    return result

# Input interface
t = int(input())
test_cases = []
for _ in range(t):
    n, m = map(int, input().split())
    grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
    test_cases.append((n, m, grid))

# Output interface
result = find_reachable_cells(t, test_cases)
for grid in result:
    for row in grid:
        print(row)
from typing import List
## main.py
from typing import List, Tuple
from collections import deque

def find_reachable_cells(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, List[str]]]) -> List[List[str]]:
    """Determines which free cells can lead the robot to the lab using BFS.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing the grid dimensions and the grid itself.

    Returns:
        A list of grids with reachable free cells marked with '+'.
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, grid in test_cases:
        # Convert grid to a list of lists for easier manipulation
        grid = [list(row) for row in grid]
        
        # Find the lab position
        lab_position = None
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == 'L':
                    lab_position = (i, j)
                    break
            if lab_position:
                break
        
        # Directions for BFS: up, down, left, right
        directions = [(-1, 0), (1, 0), (0, -1), (0, 1)]
        
        # BFS to find reachable cells
        queue = deque([lab_position])
        reachable = set()
        
        while queue:
            x, y = queue.popleft()
            for dx, dy in directions:
                nx, ny = x + dx, y + dy
                if 0 <= nx < n and 0 <= ny < m and grid[nx][ny] == '.':
                    # Count free neighbors
                    free_neighbors = 0
                    for ddx, ddy in directions:
                        nnx, nny = nx + ddx, ny + ddy
                        if 0 <= nnx < n and 0 <= nny < m and grid[nnx][nny] == '.':
                            free_neighbors += 1
                    # If the cell has at most one free neighbor, it is reachable
                    if free_neighbors <= 1:
                        grid[nx][ny] = '+'
                        reachable.add((nx, ny))
                        queue.append((nx, ny))
        
        # Convert grid back to list of strings
        results.append([''.join(row) for row in grid])
    
    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m = map(int, input().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, grid))
    
    # Output interface
    results = find_reachable_cells(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        for line in result:
            print(line)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple
from collections import deque

def find_reachable_cells(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, List[str]]]) -> List[List[str]]:
    """Find free cells from which the robot can be forced to reach the lab.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, int, List[str]]]): List of test cases, each containing grid dimensions and grid.

    Returns:
        List[List[str]]: List of processed grids with reachable cells marked.
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, grid in test_cases:
        # Convert grid to a list of lists for easier manipulation
        grid = [list(row) for row in grid]
        
        # Find the position of the lab
        lab_position = None
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == 'L':
                    lab_position = (i, j)
                    break
            if lab_position:
                break
        
        # Directions for BFS: right, down, left, up
        directions = [(0, 1), (1, 0), (0, -1), (-1, 0)]
        
        # BFS to find reachable cells
        queue = deque([lab_position])
        visited = set([lab_position])
        
        while queue:
            x, y = queue.popleft()
            
            # Check all four possible directions
            for dx, dy in directions:
                nx, ny = x + dx, y + dy
                
                if 0 <= nx < n and 0 <= ny < m and (nx, ny) not in visited:
                    if grid[nx][ny] == '.':
                        # Count free neighbors
                        free_neighbors = 0
                        for ddx, ddy in directions:
                            nnx, nny = nx + ddx, ny + ddy
                            if 0 <= nnx < n and 0 <= nny < m and grid[nnx][nny] == '.':
                                free_neighbors += 1
                        
                        # If the cell has only one free neighbor, mark it as reachable
                        if free_neighbors <= 1:
                            grid[nx][ny] = '+'
                            queue.append((nx, ny))
                    
                    visited.add((nx, ny))
        
        # Convert grid back to list of strings
        results.append([''.join(row) for row in grid])
    
    return results

# Input interface
t = int(input())
test_cases = []
for _ in range(t):
    n, m = map(int, input().split())
    grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
    test_cases.append((n, m, grid))

# Output interface
results = find_reachable_cells(t, test_cases)
for result in results:
    for row in result:
        print(row)
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple
from collections import deque

def find_reachable_cells(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, List[str]]]) -> List[List[str]]:
    """Finds the free cells from which the robot can be forced to reach the lab.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, int, List[str]]]): List of test cases, each containing the grid dimensions and the grid itself.

    Returns:
        List[List[str]]: List of modified grids for each test case.
    """
    def bfs(n: int, m: int, grid: List[str]) -> List[str]:
        """Performs BFS to determine reachable cells from the lab.

        Args:
            n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
            m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
            grid (List[str]): The grid representation.

        Returns:
            List[str]: The modified grid with reachable cells marked.
        """
        # Directions for moving in the grid: right, down, left, up
        directions = [(0, 1), (1, 0), (0, -1), (-1, 0)]
        
        # Find the lab position
        lab_pos = None
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == 'L':
                    lab_pos = (i, j)
                    break
            if lab_pos:
                break
        
        # Initialize the queue for BFS and visited set
        queue = deque([lab_pos])
        visited = set([lab_pos])
        
        # Convert grid to a list of lists for mutability
        grid = [list(row) for row in grid]
        
        while queue:
            x, y = queue.popleft()
            
            # Check all four possible directions
            for dx, dy in directions:
                nx, ny = x + dx, y + dy
                
                # Check if the new position is within bounds and not visited
                if 0 <= nx < n and 0 <= ny < m and (nx, ny) not in visited:
                    if grid[nx][ny] == '.':
                        # Count the number of free adjacent cells
                        free_adjacent = 0
                        for ddx, ddy in directions:
                            nnx, nny = nx + ddx, ny + ddy
                            if 0 <= nnx < n and 0 <= nny < m and grid[nnx][nny] == '.':
                                free_adjacent += 1
                        
                        # If there is only one free adjacent cell, mark it as reachable
                        if free_adjacent <= 1:
                            grid[nx][ny] = '+'
                            queue.append((nx, ny))
                    
                    # Mark the cell as visited
                    visited.add((nx, ny))
        
        # Convert grid back to list of strings
        return [''.join(row) for row in grid]

    # Process each test case
    results = []
    for n, m, grid in test_cases:
        results.append(bfs(n, m, grid))
    
    return results

# Input interface
if __name__ == "__main__":
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().splitlines()
    
    t = int(data[0])
    index = 1
    test_cases = []
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m = map(int, data[index].split())
        grid = data[index + 1:index + 1 + n]
        test_cases.append((n, m, grid))
        index += n + 1
    
    # Call the function
    result = find_reachable_cells(t, test_cases)
    
    # Output interface
    for grid in result:
        for row in grid:
            print(row)
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple
from collections import deque

def find_reachable_cells(t: int, test_cases: List[List[str]]) -> List[List[str]]:
    """Find free cells from which the robot can be forced to reach the lab.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[List[str]]): List of grids representing each test case.

    Returns:
        List[List[str]]: List of grids with reachable cells marked.
    """
    def bfs(grid: List[str], n: int, m: int, lab_pos: Tuple[int, int]) -> List[str]:
        """Perform BFS to find reachable cells from the lab.

        Args:
            grid (List[str]): The grid of the current test case.
            n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
            m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
            lab_pos (Tuple[int, int]): Position of the lab in the grid.

        Returns:
            List[str]: Modified grid with reachable cells marked.
        """
        directions = [(-1, 0), (1, 0), (0, -1), (0, 1)]
        queue = deque([lab_pos])
        reachable = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]
        reachable[lab_pos[0]][lab_pos[1]] = True

        while queue:
            x, y = queue.popleft()
            for dx, dy in directions:
                nx, ny = x + dx, y + dy
                if 0 <= nx < n and 0 <= ny < m and grid[nx][ny] == '.' and not reachable[nx][ny]:
                    # Check if the cell can be forced to reach the lab
                    free_neighbors = 0
                    for ddx, ddy in directions:
                        nnx, nny = nx + ddx, ny + ddy
                        if 0 <= nnx < n and 0 <= nny < m and grid[nnx][nny] == '.':
                            free_neighbors += 1
                    if free_neighbors <= 1:
                        reachable[nx][ny] = True
                        queue.append((nx, ny))

        # Mark reachable cells in the grid
        result_grid = []
        for i in range(n):
            row = []
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '.' and reachable[i][j]:
                    row.append('+')
                else:
                    row.append(grid[i][j])
            result_grid.append(''.join(row))
        return result_grid

    results = []
    for grid in test_cases:
        n = len(grid)
        m = len(grid[0])
        lab_pos = None

        # Find the lab position
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == 'L':
                    lab_pos = (i, j)
                    break
            if lab_pos:
                break

        # Perform BFS from the lab position
        modified_grid = bfs(grid, n, m, lab_pos)
        results.append(modified_grid)

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input().strip())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m = map(int, input().strip().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append(grid)

    # Call the function and print the result
    results = find_reachable_cells(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        for line in result:
            print(line)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple
from collections import deque

def find_reachable_cells(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, List[str]]]) -> List[List[str]]:
    """Finds free cells from which the robot can be forced to reach the lab.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: List of tuples containing grid dimensions and grid data.

    Returns:
        A list of grids with reachable cells marked with '+'.
    """
    def bfs(n: int, m: int, grid: List[str]) -> List[str]:
        """Performs BFS to find reachable cells from the lab.

        Args:
            n: Number of rows in the grid.
            m: Number of columns in the grid.
            grid: The grid data.

        Returns:
            Modified grid with reachable cells marked.
        """
        directions = [(-1, 0), (1, 0), (0, -1), (0, 1)]
        queue = deque()
        visited = set()
        lab_position = None

        # Find the lab position and initialize BFS
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == 'L':
                    lab_position = (i, j)
                    queue.append(lab_position)
                    visited.add(lab_position)
                    break
            if lab_position:
                break

        # Perform BFS from the lab
        while queue:
            x, y = queue.popleft()
            for dx, dy in directions:
                nx, ny = x + dx, y + dy
                if 0 <= nx < n and 0 <= ny < m and (nx, ny) not in visited and grid[nx][ny] == '.':
                    # Check if the cell can be forced to reach the lab
                    free_neighbors = 0
                    for ddx, ddy in directions:
                        nnx, nny = nx + ddx, ny + ddy
                        if 0 <= nnx < n and 0 <= nny < m and grid[nnx][nny] == '.':
                            free_neighbors += 1
                    if free_neighbors <= 1:
                        queue.append((nx, ny))
                        visited.add((nx, ny))

        # Modify the grid with reachable cells marked
        modified_grid = []
        for i in range(n):
            row = []
            for j in range(m):
                if (i, j) in visited and grid[i][j] == '.':
                    row.append('+')
                else:
                    row.append(grid[i][j])
            modified_grid.append(''.join(row))

        return modified_grid

    result = []
    for n, m, grid in test_cases:
        result.append(bfs(n, m, grid))

    return result

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m = map(int, input().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, grid))

    # Output interface
    result = find_reachable_cells(t, test_cases)
    for grid in result:
        for row in grid:
            print(row)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

requirement analysis:
The problem requires determining which free cells in a grid can force a robot to reach a lab cell, given the robot's unpredictable movement. The solution must efficiently handle large grids and multiple test cases, ensuring correct output format. The challenge lies in optimizing the algorithm to minimize computational complexity while accurately identifying reachable cells.

- Ensure the solution handles the maximum input constraints.
- Optimize the algorithm for computational efficiency.
- Provide clear and correct output for each test case.
- Test the solution with various edge cases.
We will use a breadth-first search (BFS) algorithm to determine which free cells can force the robot to reach the lab. BFS is suitable for this problem as it efficiently explores all possible paths from the lab to other cells, ensuring we find all reachable cells. We will utilize a queue to manage the exploration process and a set to track visited cells. The grid will be processed for each test case, and the output will be formatted according to the requirements.

We will use a breadth-first search (BFS) algorithm to determine which free cells can lead the robot to the lab. BFS is suitable for this problem as it efficiently explores all possible paths from the lab to other free cells, ensuring that we can identify all cells from which the robot can be forced to reach the lab. We will utilize a queue to manage the exploration of cells and a set to track visited cells. The grid will be processed for each test case, and the output will be formatted according to the requirements.
examples:
Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains two integers n and m (1 ≤ n, m ≤ 10^6; n ⋅ m ≤ 10^6) — the number of rows and the number of columns in the grid.

The i-th of the next n lines provides a description of the i-th row of the grid. It consists of m elements of one of three types: 

  * '.' — the cell is free; 
  * '#' — the cell is blocked; 
  * 'L' — the cell contains a lab. 



The grid contains exactly one lab. The sum of n ⋅ m over all testcases doesn't exceed 10^6.

Output

For each testcase find the free cells that the robot can be forced to reach the lab from. Given the grid, replace the free cells (marked with a dot) with a plus sign ('+') for the cells that the robot can be forced to reach the lab from. Print the resulting grid.

Example

Input


4
3 3
...
.L.
...
4 5
#....
..##L
...#.
.....
1 1
L
1 9
....L..#.


Output


...
.L.
...
#++++
..##L
...#+
...++
L
++++L++#.

Note

In the first testcase there is no free cell that the robot can be forced to reach the lab from. Consider a corner cell. Given any direction, it will move to a neighbouring border grid that's not a corner. Now consider a non-corner free cell. No matter what direction you send to the robot, it can choose a different direction such that it ends up in a corner.

In the last testcase, you can keep sending the command that is opposite to the direction to the lab and the robot will have no choice other than move towards the lab.
